description.text: Our grade 3 Safe Racer curriculum is utilizing Vernier's GoMotion sensor to record the instantaneous velocity of the car students design and build. This bracket was developed to ensure a consistent measurement by fixing the sensor at a specific angle.

I screwed up the cable to the z-axis when I built my printer. So to fix the problem I made this cable track to bundle them up together properly.

I have includes the Autodesk 123d-design files so you can tweak the parts if you thing its necessary.
You will need at least 8 track pieces of the "kabelkedja v2" and one "fäste-z-axel"- and "printer". The pieces will just clip together.

After seeming countless Cable Chains on thingiverse, I wanted to make one myself. Advantages: Simple to print with strong thin walls
Fast print (4.5 mm tall)
Scale-able
Excellent range of motion
Very little plastic to make Disadvantage: Need to heat up and bend into shape
Takes up more room on the bed than a standard Cable Chain

1) Print
2) Heat up & bend
(Trick: heat up a knife with a hot air gun and press to plastic in desired area. Allows for controlled bending)
3) Connect together.

Two on either side would be fine, but most things I have mounted on the top, didn't leave enough room for either side mount to be used.

After much searching, I was unsatisfied with the card tray holders on Thingiverse, so I designed my own in SolidWorks. They are designed around Settlers of Catan 5th Ed. copyright 2015 resource cards. These do not fit standard size bicycle playing cards.

I borrowed Walter's technique (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:784951) for housing neodymium magnetic balls so that the trays stay together and can easily be re-arranged. This design uses 5mm dia. magnets.

Can be printed in any material. The prints shown are in ABS and PLA. Printed on a Flashforge Creator Pro using ReplicatorG.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal to J-Head MK V

description.text:
Situation

So you broke your Ubis hotend and don't have time to buy another, but you do have a J-Head lying around? Then -- wow -- that's a pretty specific situation you have there, but at least now you can do something about it.

How

At first it looks like this isn't possible, the J-Head is too short to mount in a Simple Metal. But it can be done, there are two methods for using a J-Head on a Simple Metal:

  1. Print a mount which holds the J-Head low enough to pretend it's an Ubis.
  2. Modify the printer to accept the shorter J-Head.

These files help you achieve option 2.

Lift Bed

To use the J-Head, you have to raise the print bed on longer M3 bolts (20-30mm) (available online) with springs (available at Home Depot in the door hardware section). To raise the bed you should lower the X axis belt, one way of doing this is by laser cutting or printing the extensions from here and mounting them to the print bed with M3 bolts and zip ties.

Smaller Fan Shroud

Then you need to print a shorter fan shroud that doesn't drop below the new hotend. I've uploaded a kinda OK one here.
Designed with Inkscape and FreeCAD.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 LED Light Bar

description.text:
Wanted a way to video record overnight 3D prints without leaving the room lights on. Since I had several Harbor Freight 3-1/2 in. 9 LED Mini Flashlights laying around, I decided to put them to use in this LED light bar design for my Monoprice Maker Select 3D printer (rebranded Wanhao Duplicator i3).

The required non-printed parts:

  1. Six LED flashlights (often free at Harbor Freight).
  2. Four 2mm small screws (can be replaced by glue).
  3. Some small insulated wire to power the LEDs.

There are two light bar configurations: One that focuses all six LED downward in parallel (straight), and another that focuses each to a separate area of the Wanhao Duplicator' print bed when rear mounted (wanaho_rm).

Each configuration includes brackets for mounting the light bar in front (fm) of the the gantry, in view, or behind it (rm), hidden from view. The photos above of my installation show an example of the wanaho_rm mounted in the rear.

It should not take much effort to create a mounting bracket for other printers...

The measured operating power of the resulting light bar is 1.8 watts! So it should not impact your power bill if it runs continuously:)

Designs

Choose which lamp design bar and mounting configuration you prefer and print the required parts.

Although rendered STL models have been provided for each part with each configuration (see stl-models.zip), only two files are required from the list below to print all the parts needed to assemble a light bar.

wanhao_rm-build_plate_1o2.stl
wanhao_rm-build_plate_2o2_Xm.stl

straight-build_plate_1o2.stl
straight-build_plate_2o2_Xm.stl

For front or rear light bar mounting, replace Xm with fm or rm respectively in the second build plate.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I obtained best results using Slic3r on the light bar brackets.

Remove the LED PCB and rear switches from the six flashlights. Use a rotary tool with a cutting disc to cut a small slit along the edge parallel to the flashlight body and then peal it open with pliers.

Pinch and gently pull the rubber switch cover to reveal the switch and pry out the switch with a small screw driver.

Trim the switch terminals and drill small holes to facilitate the solder connection.

Build the wire harness to power the light bar and place in wire channel of the printed body.

Solder the leads to each PCB and power switch on the support bracket. The inner circle of LED leads are the positive terminals.

Insert the switch and switch cover/plug into the switch bracket and assemble the light bar.

The small rectangular bracket-lock is placed onto the bracket prior to inserting the light bar and is subsequently pushed downward to lock the bar clip in-place.

Mount the assembled light on your printer and connect to a powers source. The total current draw is less than 500ma at 4.5v and can easily be powered by the printers power supply, a USB plug, etc. For example, when powering at 5 volts, add a 1 milli-ohm resistor in series to provide a suitable voltage drop.

description.text:
Revision A.

  1. Added stabilizer rods to the z axis due to excessive wobble from the lead screw.

This project was inspired by Root 2 CNC beautiful work done by sailorpete. This CNC machine will replace a previously built CNC called Bertha 2.0. The CNC machine was built with the following modifications:

  1. Increased the machine size.

  2. Added Nema 23 mounts to accommodate for larger Nema 23 motors.

  3. The machine was also modified to fit a standard 1" square tubing purchased from Home Depot or any other hardware stores.

  4. Spindle holder was redesigned to accept a 1/4 HP router from Harbor Freight.

The idea behind the project was to build a good CNC machine with readily available materials and a 3D printer. At the time of this write up, I am still building my machine and the only axis that I have working properly is the Y axis. The other axis are awaiting for pulleys and belts.

title: Wilson II hotend mount for Bowden extruder

description.text: This is a redesigned hot end mount based on the original Wilson II design files from https://github.com/mjrice/Wilson2 . The goal was to change the original hot end mount to use a Bowden extruder, and reduce the detail and mass of the mount to simplify printing while increasing strength.

I have been trying to improve print quality of my Wilson II so I'm attempting to replace the direct-drive extruder mounted just above the hot end with a Bowden extruder. The main goal is to move the extruder motor to the frame and off the print head mount. Reducing the energy needed to move the print head - and importantly, the energy needed to stop it once it's in motion - should reduce backlash and 'ghosting' on prints and allow for faster printing; that's the theory anyway.

Starting with the original Wilson II hot end mount design files, I removed as much unnecessary detail as I could while adding additional material around the filament guide to give the downstream push-fit connector of the Bowden extruder more support.

Sketchup is not really appropriate for mechanical design but I didn't have a lot of choice since the orginal files were in Sketchup. It was sort of like doing CAD with a broom and the design is far from optimal. There are issues when converting the model to an STL file and to a tool path; an imperceptible amount of 'debris' on the bottom surface of the model causes Cura to render a few small 'islands' around the nut holes before filling in the main bottom layer which leads to poor print adhesion. This was solved by telling Cura to sink the print 0.5 mm into the print bed which led to a solid bond to the print bed. You will probably need to do the same so review the model before printing!

Depending on how sloppy your printer is, you may have to drill out some of the holes. The model tolerances are a bit too high for my comfort, but I don't have enough patience to try to get Sketchup to do detail work without breaking everything.

I used Tech2C's remix of the Compact Bowden Extruder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767951 for the motor mount, though it needs some work to attach it to the 8020 frame of the Wilson II. Some drilling is necessary to expand the filament inlet on top of the to accept the threaded push-fit connector for the PTFE tube; bore this out to match your specific fitting.

At the time of posting this, I'm in the middle of grinding down bits of the mount so the hot end fit is not so snug.

This is my first design, and while it's derivative and simplistic, it seems workable. I invite you to remix and extend this model; please let me know if you can make it work for you or if you have any improvements you'd like to share

remixed_from.author: gcb
remixed_from.title: Arcade push button as cherry MX keycap

description.text:
What

This is a low cost, printable AT button. It interfaces with any standard 3.5mm mono jack system, commonly found in support situations for people living with physical disabilities.

AT buttons are a way for someone with a limited range of motion to control his or her environment at the same level as anyone else. These buttons can be used to adapt toys and home appliances such that they can be actuated with ease. Most AT buttons available are quite expensive, and are engineered to be used in serious -- 100% reliability -- situations. As a result there are a lot of DIY projects to make buttons meant for more relaxed use cases. We wanted to make a button that can be used for toy adapting and similar functions, while also providing a clean and durable design.

Why

This button was created as part of a team-based senior design course. We worked with a local organization, UCP and TASC of Huntsville, to design and construct an AT keyboard and AT button.

How

Making one button takes me about 8 hours of printing and 1 hour of assembly.

Materials

  • Cherry MX Switch
  • 3.5mm Mono Port
  • 6" or so of wire
  • Optional: Compression spring for adjusting the button's actuation force.
  • Optional: 3.5mm Mono cable to connect the button to things
  • Optional: drawer/shelf/toolbox liner or dual-lock or velcro as a grip base

Assembly

  • Print the button base, button hatch, and and key cap.
  • Solder the MX switch to the mono port with two pieces of wire, about 3 inches each.
  • Install the MX switch in the middle of the button base, and then run the mono jack to the port on the flat side. Screw the mono port's threads into the hole in the side of the button.
  • Jam the key cap onto the cherry MX switch. This can optionally be done with a light spring over the switch stem to adjust the force of the button.
  • Optionally glue or bolt (M3 bolts) the shelf liner to the bottom of the button to make a no-slip base!

Can also optionally have superglue to hold things together.

Doing Things With AT Button

Here I'm just running through some small use cases that I've personally found for this button.

Control a computer via an Arduino

You can use a small firmware on an arduino along with a shell script to automate tasks on your computer. In the example code the shell script uses xdotool to generate a Right arrow key press, which allows me to use the button to advance slides in a power point.

Control a computer via microphone input

You can also wire the button directly to a computer's microphone and detect button presses. This is still something we're looking into, and hope to return with more robust code.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I print the base piece at a low-infill to save plastic, but higher infills give you a very satisfying heft.

Programs

Designed with Inkscape, OpenSCAD, and FreeCAD.

Keycap

The key cap was made with OpenSCAD files from gcb's repo.

Anti-Warp

I had a lot of trouble with warping and lift-off with these large parts since my printer isn't calibrated very well. To account for this, the base part has a design etched in the bottom of it to try and minimize warping. If you would rather not have this, please contact me and I'll work on maintaining a separate version of that file without the anti-warp pattern.

comments.text: Thank you for pursuing this switch concept! For years our school has been the proving ground for a major adaptive switch manufacturer. The prices they charge are beyond our students reach financially so once they graduate they are left without the resources they need to communicate effectively. We have a 3D printer now and are excited to send our students home with communication switches they can keep and use post graduation! Keep up the great work!

9/24/13 Update: I added an extra routine to the picture module to slice it up in 2 x nozzle widths. This allows the lid to be printed at less than 100% infill without hurting the lithophane. I think it also looks better with all the lines running the same way. Talk about useful!
You can make this pencil box set in whatever configuration you need.
You can personalize it with your favorite photo, quote, and even put your name on it.
When you have all your supplies stored inside, lock the box with your unique pencil topper key. You can rest easy knowing your things are protected in your one of a kind locking pencil box.
You need a ruler? How long? What about a protractor? Do you need metric or imperial units? Don't fret, because you can choose the best fit for your needs. It is possibly the most customizable thing on thingiverse, so if you don't have patience for slow OpenSCAD, "don't come around here no more!"
You can use the example STL files, but your kids probably will not be very amused! Pieces you get:
1 body with customizable size and dividers.
1 ruler with customizable configuration and decorations.
1 pencil topper with customizable logo that acts as a key for the box.
1 lid with captured latch mechanisim
1 lid without latch (for dualstrusion)
1 latch (for dualstrusion) Please read the instructions for specific part customizing tips, or use the customizer text with each setting. I think it is pretty straight forward. Continue below for the custom features of the customizer user interface. Thanks for using my creation, it was a lot of work! Customizer user interface challenges and solutions: You cannot change default rotation during the customization, you only get one chance at getting it right. I used rotate and translate to reorient the parts for different viewing angles. Check out the assembly of all parts in the "Slicing and printing" tab! Export multiple STL. The theory behind the "part" parameter is a good one. You choose to view and customize each part, then customizer exports them all. The problem is, if you set up custom views (see above), customizer will export a lot of unprintable garbage. You also must have the part parameter visible to the user for this function to work. I overcame this by using the customizer tabs to set up and display custom views. The part parameter is in the printer platform setup tab. It just controls the views there, so you can see the orientation with the build plate. When you create your thing, the display_tab parameter goes to the default setting (mine is ""). This triggers the export part module, which cycles through only the parts I want exported. This is a big .scad file with lots of modules. I could not avoid using some hull() and minkowski() functions, despite the warnings on the best practices page. I used a default value for $fn on applicable modules, then when the export part module is called, it is overwritten with a larger value. I used a custom polygon shape to mask the corners of the drawing canvas, so the design will not extend past the round key. I also added a custom shape to the same routine that makes the MakerBot logo! I found that if you have a variable parameter used for text input that contains an underscore like "key_text", the customizer version of Write.scad will not handle it. Use one word variables instead like "keytext". Sometimes when you edit a thing that is a work in progress, the check box gets magically unchecked. I overcome this by checking! User MichaelAtOz pointed out a customizer error when the display tabs are not in full view. I wrote in an error check for this situation to alert the user to click the arrows and try again. Please download my script, and use parts of it to make your customizable things easier to use! Bob

Before you begin, here is how the customized thing works overall.
The rounded objects are intentionally set to a low resolution for display purposes.
They are refined when you create your thing.
Please uncheck publish your thing, unless it is fun and useful for others. Instead, you should use the "I made one" function to post your pencil box photo link here.
All the parts will be created in your own thing, so don't try to export one part at a time.
Take your time to make sure everything is set how you want before committing. It takes quite a while for your results.
As always, I am open to comments or suggestions. The first tab is "Lid inside settings". Here is what you can do:
Choose from custom decorations for the inside of your lid.
You can choose a text block with up to 6 lines of text. Choose the font, height, letter spacing, and line spacing.
You can choose a lithophane style image.
You get either text or image centered, text and image with options for the left / right orientation, or you can choose none, and make all of my hard work for nothing! The second tab is "Lid inside content", where you get to make your selections on the previous tab count!
You can input a 100x100 image and invert the image. Don't forget to visit the Slicing and Printing tab to set up your items!
Update in V2.0 - Your image is now sliced vertically into 2*nozzle widths, so you can print the lid at less than 100% infill without hurting the lithophane image!
There are six places for text. Leave any you don't want blank. I have some suggestions set as defaults, so make sure to change them before you create your items. The next tab is "Lid outside". Here, you will be able to input your name, or anything else you want into the two text spots that are on either side of the latch. You can select different setting for this text than what is inside.
Tip: use this view, or the design key view to make sure your outside and inside text doesn't overlap. Now you get to "Customize body".
Here, you will select the overall dimensions of your pencil box, and set your divider orientation.
Dividers the long way (X direction) go from side to side, and you can choose to have from 1 to 3 sections this way.
Dividers the short way (Y direction) go from side to side if you don't have any long ones, or from the catch side to the first long divider. You can choose to have from 1 to 4 sections this way, and with the long way, we are now up to 6 sections! But wait, there's more!
If you set the center to "yes", the short dividers are repeated in the center section of 2 long dividers.
You can have one big box, or up to 9 sections divided up! Now we come to the reason why this OpenSCAD file is slow on Customizer "Design key".
In the lid tabs, you may have noticed that there was no latch. This view shows the latch and corresponding key with the lid for reference. The key is a pencil topper that you use as a screwdriver to lock the pencil box.
You can choose from the MakerBot logo, put in your initials, or draw your own key. I have set the default to make the pencil box and ruler designs right reading, but you can change that too!
The logo and text portions are pretty easy, but here is how the "Draw" feature works:
There is now a circular canvas to draw in. You cannot go out of the lines, or you will be penalized one stroke. The revert to default button brings back the empty circle. Where did the "Easter" bunny go? Maybe he is lurking in the text box.... No, I have said too much. Now, on to the "Ruler".
You get to choose the length with both inches and centimeters represented.
You get to choose a type of ruler or protractor, and finally, choose whether or not to include some of the customized content from the previous tabs.
Update: You can now use different text on the ruler, and select the text options here as well. The text font affects the numbers on the ruler, but thier height is set in stone... I mean plastic. ;-) On the "Printer platform setup" tab, along with the standard build plate settings, you get to see a list of parts that will be exported. When you choose items in this box it doesn't affect the parts themselves, but you can view the print orientation based on the build plate. "Slicing and printing"
Just because you are a trooper, and made it all the way to the last tab, I have a treat for you! The view is setup to show you all your new stuff!
You need to do some work, however. Set your nozzle, layer height, number of layers for the image (if you chose that), and if you want helper disks on the sharp corners of your items.
If you get the customizer error message, use the left / right arrows near the tabs to get the tab to be more visible, and then try again. Now, get to it!

title: Ethernet Cable Runners - Screw Mount Type
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Ethernet Cable Runners have proven to be extremely popular as a simple solution to keep your Ethernet cables neat, under control and easy to access, insert and remove.

The stl files provided here include a screw mount to make them attachable to walls, shelves, partitions and other internal structures. They are the same design as my earlier posted cable tie versions which can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1320948. I decided to add these as a separate listing due to the number of files provided in the range.

The screw fixing range accommodates from 2 to 16 cables. Each slot only ever accepts up to 2 cables. This ensures you can easily access and remove inner cables...the maximum that can be outside it is one.

The Ethernet Cable Runners are all small blocks that print quickly so are an easy and cost effective solution to an everyday issue in offices, buildings and at home. Print lots and a range so you've always got the right one to fulfil your need at the time.... Tidy up your cables today!

And, if you find the cables you're using vary from common size Ethernet cables, just uniformly scale them to suit.

Please refer to the images and print instructions for further information.

Note: If you like these check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

3 shells / 50% or more infill recommended to ensure they are strong... particularly the versions holding large numbers of cables.

Notes:

To make sure these work well print them strong by using 3 shells and 50% infill. They work great in PLA. They should also print well in ABS. No support required. Raft is your choice.

If you find the cables you're using vary from common size Ethernet cables, just uniformly scale them to suit.

comments.text: Does anyone know how much to scale these to fit cat 6 cables?
comments.author: medo145

comments.text: The hole through the standard size Ethernet cable runner is 5.75mm. The opening is 4mm. You can use the hole size to scale yours to suit. The problem is there are several varieties with slightly different diameters but, for example, you use 6.25mm the scaling is 6.25 / 5.75 x 1.087 (8.7%). Scaling uniformly is recommended. I hope this helps...
comments.author: medo145

comments.text: I found I needed to scale up 25% in the two dimensions that affect the hole size... no reason to scale up the thickness. Now I need to figure out how to eliminate the "elephant foot" effect, because a thin and sharp flange turns these into insulation strippers.
comments.author: muzz64

comments.text: The instructions provided explain scaling up and that is required for some cables... as not all cables are the same. It sounds like you have CAT6, not the thinner standard Ethernet cables. If you scale up uniformly the edge shouldn't be as sharp as you describe... I haven't had any other reports of them doing this and thousands have been downloaded. I hope this helps....
comments.author: rsworden

comments.text: I did not mean to imply that the elephant foot had anything to do with these designs or scaling them. It's a result of settings on my printer that I needed to learn to deal with. The elephant foot has been annoying on several things I've printed, because it makes the bottom edge sharp and uncomfortable to handle. For these clips, it's sharp enough to actually slice the cable insulation as I slide cables in and out. After fixing that, the holes are more open and I only needed to scale up 8 to 12 percent to fit CAT6 cables.

title: Wind tunnel out of a Leaf blower hack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So, I was challenged to find the dead air behind an object. Not that hard right? Well, here's the catch, I can only use what I can find in shop class. Fortunately for me, there is a 3D printer, a leaf blower, some wood, spare vex parts, and a digitizer there. All I needed now was a photogate! I'll explain more later on. But in short, what I am showing here is the adapter I made for the leaf blower ensure equal fair flow across the wooden wind tunnel.

In short, we have a 3 axis arm that has a digital switch (photogate) triggered when air flows, and when it goes from flowing air to non flowing air it makes a point using the Digitizer ... After a while there isn't any more dead air space, and you have a 3d printable model of the dead air space. All for less than a spool of plastic, $30 leaf blower, $5 photogate, 3 motors, and a microscripe (note you could use encoders if you wanted to, but we had the microscribe and wanted to make our lives easy.)

Yeah I never got around to finishing this... Kinda graduated first and all of it was still in my highschool.

So with 1 shell, it took a mere 18 hours to print this beast with 250+grams of plastic. This was with bumping up some extrude speeds too. I would not advise printing this unless you have a lot of time to let it do it's thing.

So I started off with this sketch. It allowed me to get a general idea of what shape it would be. (note the angled corners) The next step was to make the little clip that would secure it to the leaf blower (cutting extrusion, vertical extrude up, then some more extrudes and fillets to get the thing right) re Then simply loft one square to the correlating square in sketch 10 (make sure the loft is a new solid so you can shell it) and repeat till all 16 lofts are done This is what 16 lofts done looks like then mirror solid the 16 new solid objects twice. (giving you all 4 quadrants filled based off of one quadrant of work) and combine everything back into one solid using the combine feature Then well, I did an extrude to and touched it up some with some fillets, threw it into an assembly and toda final digital mockup

description.text:
Here you have the Anti-Materiel Rifle from Fallout New Vegas. BOOYA!

The model was pulled from the actual game files and scaled to the length of a PGM Hécate II, the real-world basis for the model. Since all of the round bits were low-poly, I made them higher poly cylinders/balls so they would be cleaner and more realistic. I then broke it down into bits that will fit in my 8”x10”x8” build area and the wooden pieces specifically separated out. The clip has a round protruding from the top with a matching recess in the bolt so you can look cool when you pull it out and show those petty wastelanders at your local convention.

The big improvement is that everything is now keyed for proper orientation. Using the keys, your part won't slide around as you bond them together and everything will be clocked correctly.

You will need to print 4 of the AssemblyKeySmall_fixed and 14 of the AssemblyKeyLarge_fixed to key everything together. I recomend scaling them down 5% to allow for easier fitment.

Everything should be oriented in the way I think will print best, but go on ahead and put the face of the part on the build plate you feel is best.

I also included a file of the whole thing for reference and a .50 round in case you want to print some for a belt/bandoleer and look like a real hard-ass who is prepared for some battle!

Now go fourth and cleanse the Wastelands!

description.text:
My first thing and my first project in OpenSCAD - feedback is welcome!  
This is a toggle that would go on each end of a length of bungee cord.  In particular it is designed to replace the toggles that you get on rubber dinghies to hold the oars in place.

Download either the sgl (single) or dbl (double) STL file, which are pre-configured for 5mm and double-5mm shock cord respectively. Alternatively download the OpenSCAD source file and edit to your requirements. Generate STL and Gcodes in the normal way and print using your 3D printer.
Cut the shock/bungee cord to length and insert through hole.
Tie a tight knot in the end with the large hole and pull knot into the body of the toggle.
Insert the bung in the large hole (you may need to glue in place).

comments.text:
Outstanding design, thanks for sharing! This is exactly what I've been looking for. I had to scale down the z axis to 92.4% when I sliced it in Cura so I could fit the print on my fabrikator mini, and it looks like I'll have to dremel out about 2mm so the spool will sit flat. It fits the .5kg spools fine, but the 1kg spools catch on the slopes at the shoulder joint and the tail at the end. The fab mini has a 80mm x80mm x 80mm build volume, so I only miss it by a few millimeters. If the end of the spool holder terminated into a sharp 90 deg, or even 45 deg, with about 3-5mm of thickness instead of the sloped shoulder to keep the spool from sliding off, then scaling it down it would be a cinch. If you ever think about doing a revision, please consider that - the FabMini owners would be grateful :)
Thanks again for a great design!

description.text:
UPDATE: 11/3/16 There was a problem with the file for the Inner Bicep Ring. Thank you xombie4less for finding it. I have replaced the file.

I've had the idea of making an Exo-Suit for many years, only recently with the help of 3D printing was I able to do something with it. I created this suit to be mobile and not too bulky. It has many attachment points for add-ons such as armor. I will be, in the future, adding to this to make a full body exoskeleton.

I wanted to make a video to show how well it moves but I am currently recovering from neck surgery.

Everything was printed on a Simple Metal 6x6x6 printer which created a lot of engineering challenges. I overcame these by making it modular, which in turn helped with the design process, if I made a change I did not have to reprint a large section.

All the bearing used are based off my EZ-BB bearing, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1476521 .(I used around 500 BBs) and rest of the parts are held together with pins. I personally don't like the idea of using glue and screws.

Please read all the information attached to this thing, It is complex,will use over 2kg of PLA and take several days to print.

For rafts and supports I used as few as possible but they were needed on some parts. This will depend on your printer and what it can do. I found anything with a tab needed supports that touched the build-plate and parts with slots, without any supports, these parts needed a little clean-up to fit properly. Excessive force should not be needed to assemble any parts.

Most of the files will only need to be printed once per arm except the arm struts and Elbow bearing, you will need to print each of these two times.

The assembly instructions are in picture form.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1984

Infill:

25%+

Notes:

If you are going to make this don't get cheap. I printed most of the parts at 0.8mm top/bottom/sides and 25% infill. The small pins file needs to be to be printed at 100% infill.

This plug seals up the hole in the side of the gearbox that allows access to the set screw and prevents oil from spilling out of the gearbox as well as keeping dirt out.

My senior design project used 9 of these gearboxes on a robot that traveled in sand. This bolt on plug kept the internals lubricated and clean so we didn't have to keep rebuilding them.

I used 10-32 x 3/8 bolts to mount them, though 10-32 x 1/4 should work as well.

Note: when oiling the gearbox, run them in clean conditions for a few minutes first to allow excess oil to drain out. If excess oil gets trapped inside, it will try to get into the motor.

title: Gargoyle - Negative Mold for Low Melt casting in ABS

description.text:
This is a negative mold for printing in ABS and casting with
low melt point metals like Rose's Metal, Field's Metal, etc.
Don't mess around with this stuff if you don't know what you
are doing. I take no responsibility for anyone that melts their face off,
gives themselves lead poisoning, etc,

UPDATE: Added a v2 mold with a pouring hole and air vent.
May need to drill out these holes to ensure they are clear prior to
pouring. Keep pouring until the metal is close to the top of the larger
hole to ensure enough hydrostatic pressure to properly fill the area
near the Gargoyle's feet. My v1 open top mold resulted in a lot of
artifacts near the feet. This v2 mold was designed to correct that.
Uses a lot more plastic, unfortunately :(

title: Mini Arcade videogame with Raspberry Pi 2

description.text:
This Arcade videogame uses a Raspberry Pi 2 board with 7 " display and a suitable shield for button management. The front panel backlight is achieved by 2 RGB LED modules whilst the whole system is powered by 5VDC/2A switching power supply. All sides of the cabinet are made with a 3D printer with an adeguate size printing plate (such as the 3drag BIG) and are fixed together by M4x12 countersunk screws and M4 bolt.
Info http://www.open-electronics.org/buiding-an-arcade-coin-op-machine-to-rediscover-the-80-90s-with-retropie/

BOM

• 1x type B Raspberry Pi 2 board
• 1x RetroPie Shield for Raspberry Pi
• 1x 7" Touch Screen Monitor for Raspberry Pi
• 2x 8 LED RGB WS2812 Neopixel Stick
• 1x Beetle module for neopixel control
• 1x micro 3+3W amplifier module
• 2x 2W / 8 ohm – Ø 66mm miniature speaker
• 1x 4 axes Arcade Joystick
• 2xi GRANATA Arcade push button,
• 2x YELLOW Arcade push button
• 2x GREEN Arcade push button
• 1x BLACK Arcade push button
• 1x WHITE one player symbol Arcade push button
• 1x N.O. square push button
• 1x 8GB Micro Secure Digital
• 1x 0,7m M / M HDMI cable
• 1x DC jack to micro USB adapter cable
• 1x 5V - 2A switching power supply
• 1x panel 5,5x2,1 DC jack
• 24x 5mm Faston terminal - female
• 1x 30 cm cable with four 5,5x2,1DC plug and one DC jack
• 1x 30 cm cable with 5,5x2,1 DC plug
• 1x amplifier potentiometer knob
• 24 AWG wires for push button and other connections
• 2,54mm pin strip
• 33x M4 countersunk head screw
• 33x M4 nut

description.text:
[Note: This is still work in progress. The v2 part fits pretty well, but with a bit of dremeling. I've now added a v3 part made with OpenSCAD which should help reach a better fit, but I haven't tried it myself yet.]

FabX 2 machines use a Budaschnozzle v2 (likely, a chinese variant of it), which is mounted a few mm below the extruder assembly. The gap causes flex filaments to, well, flex occasionally and make it hard to print with them.

This thing closes the gap between the extruder assembly and the hotend, providing a near gapless path for the filament to pass through. This support has been designed to be used with an additional PTFE (or similar) tubing to provide a smoother path for the filament.

Printer:

FabX 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

I made the initial version by measuring topside of the Budaschnozzle with a pair of calipers and then modelling based on that. It turned out to be fairly inaccurate.

For the second version, I found the Budaschnozzle v2.0 drawings published by Lulzbot (https://devel.lulzbot.com/Budaschnozzle/v2.0/), which helped fixed the dimensions to an extent. I made a drawing in AutoCAD and then extruded it to get the final 3D shape. This turned out pretty well, except it needed a bit of dremelling at the corners to make it fit properly.

I made the third version from scratch in OpenSCAD. I haven't tried printing and using this yet. But this should be more accurate, and potentially be a better fit because I've used numbers from the official Budaschnozzle drawing as parameters to the design. If it doesn't fit well, it should be easy to modify it since it's an OpenSCAD model.

title: Craftbot Hidden Hinge for a Front Door

description.text:
When not in use the hinge is hidden and it opens with two pivot points. This also means that the door has to be pushed to the right before you can actually turn it open (still thinking on a solution to improve that)

It is meant to be screwed to the side panel with the already existing screw and the design should fit the right and left side of the printer.
You might have to lower your flow rate in order to break free the hinges (if you are having trouble with that).

I have also included the .dxf for the laser cut acrylic front door. You might want to modify it in order to mount a handle to it (I completely forgot about that).

I have printed it with 100% infill to make it as strong as possible and without any supports.
The holes for the acrylic are meant to accomodate 4x M4 screws and I have glued two magnets on the opposite corners with 2k epoxy in order to keep it closed.

Update:
I wasn't completely sure if a glued handle would hold up very long, so I quickly drew one that uses the existing M4 screws. It is a bit unconventional as it is mounted on opposite side where you would expect it, but I works surprisingly well.

Update2:
I have noticed that some people might have had problems with the tight tolerances (particulary when printing it with ABS), which lead to a fused and therefor unusable part. I added another version with enlarged tolerances (+0,5mm for the diameter of the holes and +0,5mm between the top/bottom and middle part)

Printer:

Craftbot

0.2mm

100%

comments.text: Pulling air out near the top of the enclosure is always better for colling down the case since the warm air inside raises to the top then pulled out by the fan. This is why factory setup with the small fan near the top should have been pulling air out not pushing it in. With 80 mm fan on this small case there is probably not much difference which way it blows. Myself I am intended to use 80 mm fan and slow it down to half speed using resistor. It will blow out.
comments.author: Shurak

comments.text: I had a difficult time getting this plate to fit my i3 PSU.  When the fan is mounted on the inside, it wants to run into all the cables coming off the wiring bus.  I also had to cut away some plastic from the IEC power cord jack (and only can use one screw) to get it to fit around the fan guard I bought.  The side of the fan gets in the way of the mounting screw on one of the sides of the box, leaving me with only two screws holding the fan to the plate.  Has anyone found a good installation solution for this part?

comments.text: Well this is up to you. But in my opinion it must suck cool air in the psu. So in my case it suck in and it comes out through side grills
comments.author: shaiss

comments.text: Actually there is a "right" way for the air to move. General best practices for cooling an enclosed space is to create a negative pressure, therefore the fan should be blowing OUT. Look at literally every computer case ever made and you'll see the same, and our printer's control box is basically just a tiny computer.
comments.author: The_Monstro

comments.text:
but with computer case fans, there is usually fan in two fans
one in front and back..
comments.author: marklein

comments.text: IF you set it up to pull in the air, it will just escape out of the box the easiest way thus leaving areas without cooling. When pushing air out, it will suck in the air from all around, taking fresh air from outside the box (those small holes around it) and cooling it more evenly... So, pls dont change the direction.. you might set the printer on fire accidentally and burn down the house, secially in US and other paper-made homes.
comments.author: marklein

comments.text: Cant see any differencein your logic.  sucking in air will make it go the shortest way possible on top of the electronics.

//same thing as the alpha except that i added a ".scale(0.5)" on the end of line 204
//même chose que l'alpha sauf que j'ai ajouté ".scale(0.5)" à la fin de la ligne 204

beta source code javascript OpenJsCad run screenshot My project. Mon projet.

  • I:

  • printed the beta twice using an Ultimaker^2 printer and created supports using Cura and about 1.55m of PLA (print time = about 1h)
  • then picked off the supports with fingers and tweezers, and filed down the rough edges.
  • created the stickers using a Roland vinyl cutter and gold vinyl sheets (they are 15 by 40 mm stickers in size 14 Courrier New font with a needle pressure of 90).
  • painted one coat of hemp colored acrylic paint, one coat of mat black spray paint, some splotches of red spray paint (to give the illusion of mahogany), and some splotched of silver spray paint (because why not).

  • sprayed on some strong glue to support the flimsy vinyl-sticker adhesive

  • J'ai:

  • imprimé deux versions du beta grace à une imprimante Ultimaker^2 et créé des supports grace à Cura et à environ 1.55m de fil de PLA (temps d'impression = environ 1h)
  • retiré les supports à l'aide de doigts, de pinces, et limé les restes rugueux.
  • créé les autocollants grace à une découpeuse vinyle Roland et à des chutes de vinyle doré (ce sont des autocollants de 15 par 40 mm chacun en Courrier New taille 14 avec une pression d'aiguille égale à 90).
  • peint une couche d'acrylique couleur chanvre, une couche de bombe noire-mat, quelques taches de bombe rouge (pour donner un effet de bois d'acajou), et quelques taches de bombe argentée (parce-que pourquoi pas).
  • collé les autocollants vinyles grace à un spray de montage pour assurer une bonne tenue

Thanks to the FabLab at the Cité des Sciences in Paris, and to Gnanclub-ut7/!
Un grand merci au FabLab à la Cité des Sciences de Paris, et à Gnanclub-ut7/!

description.text:
As I had a few 8mm steel balls over from another project, I designed this 16014 ball bearing to suit the open source ciclop scanner bed. Uses 12 balls and is easy to assemble as the ball cage just clips into place.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:740357
April 8th >> Updated The 12 ball runs fine but added an 18 ball cage if you want/need the bearing to run smoother.
here's a link to where I source the steel balls >> http://www.banggood.com/50pcs-Wheel-Bearing-Balls-from-4568910MM-p-967092.html

Printer:

Prusa Air 2

Resolution:

0.3-0.2

min 30%

Notes:

If you print the inner and outter ring together you may need some clean up of the retract area where the printer goes from one object to the other but nothing major

comments.text:
How did you assemble the bearing?
I have the inner /outer races and the ball track in the middle, I can get about half of the balls in it, but then it's really tight to feed in the rest as they snap in. The 18 ball version.
comments.author: Grenglund

comments.text:
So, I used a quick vise to press each bearing in with success. i.e. not cracking the inner or outer ring. Next question, how do you get it to run smoother? I made it out of ABS and am thinking to put some acetone in it and run my drill to spin the bearing so it doesn't take a seat and put dimples in the race and breaks it in a little. OR should I just grease it and run it through by hand/drill.
I've already run it around by hand for about 20 minutes and it's ok, but not nearly half way to what I'd want it for the stepper motor to turn and give me accurate results.
comments.author: Grenglund

comments.text: You shouldn't need to use any force to assemble the bearing. Im a bit concerned you may have distorted either inner or outer ring which wont help smooth running.
comments.author: Grenglund

comments.text: Stand the outer ring on end. Carefully place the 18 balls in the outer ring then insert the inner ring. Move the balls so the inner ring is centralised. Move the balls so then are evenly distributed around the races, then insert the ball cage. If you've never done this before it can be a bit tricky at first but with a bit of patience it can be done. Ive just uploaded an image to show the layout of the balls and inner ring before the inner ring is centralised and the cage can be clipped into place
comments.author: Grenglund

title: MakerSL / Openbuilds Laser Cut Tape Dispenser

description.text:
This is a simple Laser Cut Tape Dispenser. The design was inspired by this little beauty...and it was scaled for a roll of Staples 3/4" x 1296' invisible tape.

http://acuteaero.com/2010/06/03/the-most-advanced-scotch-tape-dispenser-in-the-world/

It is assembled with QTY(10) Openbuilds Low Profile M5 x 10 SHCS. The Spacers can also be made from OB supplies, simple stack whatever various lengths you want until you reach a total length of 22mm

Laser cut parts: DXF files are [provided, there as no logos in place, if you can cut/engrave acrylic than you can add your own logo. If you would like custom made acrylic parts please feel free to contact me via my website:

http://makersl.com/

Printer parts:
These parts were made from ABS and will require tapping (M5). The holes in the parts are modeled at 4.5mm however, I like to run a 4.5mm(.177") drill through them prior to tapping.

Assembly is straight forward...

Note: I have provided STL files for the Sides, the Cutter or the Spindle Caps. However, I think these are best done in acrylic, I feel it would loose it's appeal if it were fully printed, although a transparent filament might work nicely ;-)

This entire project was done using Onshape, a "view only" file is linked below:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/3f43e0c3895f16fa00ec39bd

Printer:

MakerSL Custom FT 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Rotate as required to print spacer and spindle vertically. Part all other parts flat.

remixed_from.title: X-Labs Shrike GoPro Mounts (replaces Top Plate)

description.text:
I really like the Shrike but the SMA connector is very exposed. I used the basic design from ADD1CT3DD who made a great replacement top plate which includes a gopro mount. I have printed and used his successfully but wanted something light weight for racing.

This is not perfect and i would appreciate feedback. The idea is that it sites on top of your standard carbon top plate and it there to reduce the amount of SMA connector brakes.

I also used MOSHEN's design for the SMA connection as i felt like it would fit nicely.

The complete unit only weighs 3g and i have printed it out of ABS and it feels really strong. I did think it might need some reinforcement but feeling it now it might not time will tell

author: danfinlay

print_settings.Notes:: Easy print... to make your Wolf Whistles multi-coloured pause the print at 3mm / 35 - 40% print progress.

title: Wolf Whistles... easy and fun multi pitch whistles!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Wolf Whistles are a small, easy and 'loud' prints. Keep one handy all year round for sports, in case of emergencies and fun for Halloween or use them as a small low cost gift.

The outer chambers are a different length from the centre chamber so, when blown hard, make different pitch 'ear piercing' sounds. Combined they make a loud dual pitch whistle... or place a finger/s over the outer or centre holes to change the pitch.

There are plenty of 'whistles on Thingiverse however the Wolf Whistle is as much about a fun way to present a whistle as it is about producing an actual 'wolf whistle' but, with a bit of practice and experimentation with finger positions, you can achieve sounds representing a Wolf Whistle

There are two different Wolf Whistle stl's provided. One is for a standard whistle and the other includes a facility to place it onto a key ring.

For additional information please refer to the images and print setting.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

2 shells / 50% or more

Notes:

Easy print... to make your Wolf Whistles multi-coloured pause the print at 3mm / 35 - 40% print progress.

Check the openings...

Wolf Whistles should work well straight off the build plate however check all of the openings to make sure they are clean and free of filament debris which could disrupt airflow. A well set up machines / good slicing app should deliver a sharp ready to use whistle.... just give it a good hard blow!

comments.text: Easy print. Takes a lot of air to make it whistle!
comments.author: Dryphter

comments.text: I use Replicator G to turn the .stl file to a .gcode file and lastly a .x3g file. My ctc printer only supports .x3g files and I've searched the Internet for other apps that can turn .stl to .x3g. Maybe through the process of turning .stl to .gcode to .x3g using Replicator G messes up the print. I use PLA because there is no reason to use ABS much. I also tried printing a phone case that has been tested and didn't work. Maybe Replicator G messed up the size or something. When I need full support, Replicator G prints the hardest supports to get off. When I just need supports on the bottom of a print, (usually what I do to keep them from being knocked off) I take them off and it leaves an ugly mark on my print. Do you know of any other better apps that turn .stl to .x3g but have better support generators?
comments.author: ethanlaj

comments.text: What you've described is exactly why I value my MakerBots so much... they may cost a bit more but are worth every cent because you don't waste filament and loads of time not to mention the frustration.
comments.author: ethanlaj

comments.text: This is not related to this design but you are a great designer. So maybe your an expert with 3D printers. Sometimes, when I print, my print slips of the platform and messes up my print. Do you know how to fix that?

title: Batman v/s Superman Light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Batman v/s Superman contest

light is giving a shade but its very large. In the design process we desisted that we are not going for the shade but to make the design of the light as an object.

most of the things you can print without support.

be aware that some files need support.

The design is based on the fact you should be able to print it on a 300mmx300mm bed 200mm height.

The lampshade connector you can glue to the lampshade. We have done this with our 3d pen so its welded together.

You can choose to print screws we choose to use the metal ones with we already had. The holes are for M5 bolts.

we use a E27 fitting for the lighting. With the 2 rings we clamp it on to the lampshade.

the swing arm is printed with support as well as the swing arm connector.

the leg file is printed without support. the hinge moment is printed in. if you print this with support it will not work.

You can choose different logos at the bottom or on the light it self. So print the ones you like.

good luck printing

printed with: by ctrl design filament 2,85 mm

collors: red, iron grey, silver grey, dark blue

design: by ctrl design

3D-print: by ctrl design

author: byctrldesign

print_settings.Notes:: They'll print happily individually, or all together. I did all 10 of them twice each in a single session.

title: X-Wing Miniatures - Veteran Instincts Pilot Upgrade Icons

description.text:
Saw someone using a similar type thing (possibly acrylic) on google images, though it might be a useful item to add to my X-Wing Miniatures Collection to help avoid confusion during play.

Basically, these are icons you can place on your Ship Base/Ship Pilot Card that cover the existing Pilot Score with the number you insert. They are intended for use when you are using the Veteran Instincts Upgrade which increases your pilot skill by +2. So if you were using Darth Vader (Pilot Skill 9) + Veteran Instincts, you would put the number 11 icon on the back of your ship base indicating his new pilot skill for the current squad build.

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

They'll print happily individually, or all together. I did all 10 of them twice each in a single session.

After Printing

Since the base layer usually comes out slightly thicker than the rest, you do need to trim (Stanley Knife) or file the bottom corners of the mounting arm so they fit in your ship base correctly.

Also, if you want to paint the numbers (using a felt tipped paint texta) its easier to do so while they are still on the print bed (as shown in one of my pictures).

description.text:
The original files designed by Sannyshine would always fail on the teeth and pistons when trying to print in Simplify3D.

After no joy in asking people for a fixed version I did it myself. It now prints fine with the piston in the jaw as one piece and all teeth are fused with no more floating.

Enjoy :)

Active cooling is advised.

author: akhilraju

description.text:
Et lille skilt til haven som skal laser cuttes og det er tegnet i SW og DXF god fornøjelse :)

A little sign for gardens that should be laser cut and it is in SW and DXF enjoy:)

Our booze and DnD group were fighting an ambush of Myconids, when Aaron called them Smurfs. You want Smurfs Aaron? I'll give you Smurfs!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aJV7d7UvSbW

In this case, the SCAD code of the Scout printbot has been converted into OOML code ( iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/doku.php ). At the same time, the ScoutMega printbot derives from the MiniSkyBot ( thingiverse.com/thing:7989 ) by Obijuan ( thingiverse.com/obijuan ). The castor wheel in the rear part is the same as in the MiniSkyBot, but the OOML version ( thingiverse.com/thing:12198 ) by avalero ( thingiverse.com/avalero ) was employed. Here is a small video (in spanish): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=821ua42vHks The main design is the same as the Scout printbot, but an additional front bumper has been included in order to mount on it a gripper. The gripper selected is a modification of the one posted in ( thingiverse.com/thing:2415 ). The electronics consists on an Arduino Mega board and 3 Futaba S3003 servos (for both wheels and gripper). In the attached files, all the source code is provided: SCAD files and STL. There is algo a C++ file in which it is the code of the chassis using the OOML. Additional things:
To assemble everything, you will need at least:
  • 11 M3x8mm screws.
  • 4 M3x20mm screws.
  • 14 M3 nuts.
  • 2 O-ring: 50x3 mm.
  • 1 O-ring 16x3 mm.
    • Realize that for the gripper I just used some plastic wire. You can do this as well but if you want to use screws (for a more robust coupling), you will need:
  • 6 M3x6mm screws.
  • 6 more M3 nuts.
    • TO DO:

  • The gipper is too big according the size of the chassis. This make the printbot unstable sometimes.

  • Change the design to make it easier to assemble.

  • Improve the gripper anchorage. Right now it is very difficult to assemble.
    • I'm sorry about this issues. That is what happens when an electronic design mechanics :)

• Download the zip file.

  • Print all the STL files (look at the quantity of each part). In my case, the chassis was printed in two parts.

  • Assemble all the printed parts.

  • Hack the two servos you are going to use for the wheels.

  • Mount two hacked Futaba S3003 or equivalent servos to the bracket. Mount another one (not hacked) on the gripper.

  • Mount an Arudino Mega (to mount a smaller version the mounting holes should be changed in the ScoutMega.cpp file). Maybe you need to add some weight on the rear part... the printbot is a little bit unstable.

  • Wire and program the Arduno.

  • Play and have fun!

Just another PacMan fridge magnet.
I am particularly proud of the eye...

RepRap

Prusa Mendel Metric

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

0.4 mm tip

Notes:

No support or raft needed, I use some loops to calibrate z manually, not needed. It's a very simple print.
I printed this with green ABS, If I had the right colour I would have printed it Yellow, because he's a yellow little bastard.
The standard model is 60mm diameter and magnet 12x3 mm (dia x height).
You can change this to you're specification, just check that the magnet fits within the model.
The mouth angle is customizable as well, print a ton of this and do a stop motion animation, why don't ya?

sphere scale down z

sphere, scaled down z

rotate to fit correct place.

Make everything as a calculation of diameter.

description.text:
This mount is to place standard electric switch on the bar or the bicycle.
I've designed it to make comfortable light switch right after hand.
As a switch I've used the one which is very popular, say, in computer power supplies.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Notes:

Thing is designed for bar d=22.5mm (which is appliable for the most of the bars).
One trick is to print it without support, and in order to have good bridge I've added a thin layer between the hole for the wire and the volume for switch body.
When printing with layer =0.15mm it will create exactly one layer of support.

I print it using PLA. It is strong enough to be place on the bar over it. If you use another filament, you may be need to put out the grip and place the holder from the side of the bar.
You need small bolt M3, length about 5-7mm to fix it. (no need for nut).

description.text:
Just another ghost (PacMan) fridge magnet.
After having made Pac-Man I sensed he was a tad lonely, needed some friends...

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa Mendel Metric

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm layers

Infill:

10% hex

Notes:

Like PacMan, it's a very simple print. I guess almost all settings would work, just use some infill so that the top cover have something to rest upon. The less infill the smaller magnet you can use (weight).
Glue or press-fit your magnet in place. I printed with ABS so a little acetone where the magnet wouldn't stay on to glue it there.

sphere+cylinder, scaled down z

added some cylinders rotateted at 45 degree angle cross for skirt and deleted every other a little transposed in y, making it a wavy false sinus curve.

Added eyes, one smaller sphere deleted from a slightly larger, scaled down and rotated and translated into right position.

Parametric
magnet_diameter = 12;
magnet_height = 3;

ghost_diameter = 60;
ghost_thickness = 33; //percent
ghost_fold_amount = 3.5;

the four smaller magnet-figures are diameter 30mm, the bigger ones with pacman is 60mm

Diameter is the width, thickness is in percent, 33% makes 60mm into 10mm height. fold amount is the number of full false sinus waves of the ghost skirt.

If someone wants to parametrisize the eyes so that you can give the ghost different expressions I'd like to see that, so feel free to customize this.

description.text: Your 3D you! Scanned and uploaded by the Edinburgh International Science Festival, www.sciencefestival.co.uk

title: All year round Solar garden light

description.text:
I was motivated to design this solar light because I was fed up with the poor performance from commercial lights.
The solar panel is one watt and the battery storage is a 10Ah rechargeable D cell. I'm using a 100uH inductor which gives 10mA into the LED and 33mA drain from the cell this gives a very adaqate light and the LED is very over rated for the job so long life and low phosphor degradation will hopefully be the outcome.
The chip used is a QX5252F this is commonly available from eBay an this wonderfully pragmatic design which has other uses I'm sure, here is the data sheet which is not comprehensive. http://www.mikrocontroller.net/attachment/158139/QX5252.pdf
The solar cells in the round design are very old monocrystalline cells they are very thick and hard to break and easy to work with I have hundreds of them, I realise this is not fare on you and have produced two alternative panels with modern cells which can be obtained from eBay.
There are two types; 19mm x 52mm cells two series banks of four connected in parallel to give two volts at 500mA. And ; 38mm x 52mm cells connected in series to give two volts at 500mA. I have tried both options some skill is required when soldering these cells as they are VERY easy to break. There are encapsulated cells 53mm x 18mm which I have not tried which in theory would fit but only give half the output.
The Perspex top is 4-5mm thick and is easily bent to shape with a hot air paint stripper the shape does serve some purpose as this diffracts and reflects light around. This would work with a plane square top but not be so effective. The Perspex top is glued with epoxy to the panel and the body is fixed to the panel with acetone for ABS (which I am using) and epoxy for PLA (don't know how long this lasts outside).
I have made channels in all the parts to accommodate the wiring and make it easy to assemble without a PCB which maybe novel I'm not sure and would not want to steel any credit.
The D cell holder has extra pads on the corners to stop it lifting and bridging supports on the socket groove all need removing.
The negative contact on the D cell is just a strip of phosphor bronze .2mm thick. I had some knocking around but I see that Rapid sells it.
The spike is a piece of 8mm stainless steel but a bit of zinc plated studding would do if that's what you have.
The connectors I have used are turned pin header and socket which comes in strips and can be cut to size. The output I have plugged onto the end of the LED wires as a plug seemed an unnecessary luxury.
Ill include lots of pictures which I hope will help with construction but please ask if you would like to make one and you have issues.
PS

The funny L shape on the Large square panel is an insulator as one tabbing strip passes over the other.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa Mendel

No

No

.2mm layer with .5mm nozzel

40%

How to assemble the circuit into the solar fixing assembly. I do apologies for the camera work but I'm not equipped for filming and doing at the same time . Start of assembly of the battery module. Sand down front of panel as this will warp a bit. This will glue to the Perspex evenly. Now give it a wash. Tab cells on the back first. These are my old cells do not try and tin modern cells on the back,tin the tabbing and use a flux pen Cells ready to place into the panel. These cells are positive on the top modern cells are negative on top. You can tin the top of modern cells.

comments.text:
Hi daGHIZmo I take it you require more specifics with the circuit which is as simple as can be because of this excellent chip QX5252F the 4 pinned transistor version. If you go to eBay you can get them from China for a few euros (very cheap) and maybe someone local sells them on at a markup saving the long wait from China.
I'll get onto the parts list and more pictures of the circuit assembly today now I have printed some green fixings the black components will show up better rather than the black on black at the moment. Give me a day and let me know if you need more info.
I'm also considering a film on bending the Perspex top and soldering the solar cells.
Thanks for you interest.
